patientHistory.description: Diagnosed with PCOS after presenting with irregular menstrual cycles, hirsutism, and elevated androgen levels. Ultrasound showed characteristic polycystic ovaries.
patientHistory.notes: Patient responds well to current treatment regimen. Blood glucose levels stable.

patientHistory.description: Secondary hypothyroidism likely related to PCOS and metabolic syndrome. TSH elevated at 8.5 mIU/L, T4 low normal.
patientHistory.notes: Thyroid function normalized after 6 months of treatment. Annual monitoring required.

patientHistory.description: Insulin resistance identified through glucose tolerance test. HOMA-IR score of 4.2 indicates significant insulin resistance.
patientHistory.notes: Patient following low-glycemic diet. HbA1c improved from 6.1% to 5.7%.

diagnosisTreatment.description: Multiple functional ovarian cysts detected on transvaginal ultrasound. Cysts range from 2.5-4.2cm in diameter.
diagnosisTreatment.treatmentPlan: Combination oral contraceptives to suppress ovulation and prevent new cyst formation. Monthly monitoring with ultrasound for 3 months, then quarterly.
diagnosisTreatment.treatmentResponse: Significant reduction in cyst size noted at 6-week follow-up. Patient reports decreased pelvic pain.
diagnosisTreatment.notes: Consider switching to continuous cycling if breakthrough bleeding persists.

diagnosisTreatment.description: Meets 4/5 criteria for metabolic syndrome: elevated waist circumference (94cm), high triglycerides (185mg/dL), low HDL (38mg/dL), elevated blood pressure (138/86), and insulin resistance.
diagnosisTreatment.treatmentPlan: Weight loss goal of 10% body weight through caloric restriction and exercise. Metformin for insulin sensitivity. Mediterranean diet counseling.
diagnosisTreatment.treatmentResponse: Patient has lost 6kg over 4 months. Triglycerides decreased to 145mg/dL. Blood pressure improved.
diagnosisTreatment.notes: Excellent compliance with lifestyle modifications. Consider adding statin if LDL remains elevated.

medicalTest.results: Right ovary: 3.2 x 2.8 x 2.1 cm, multiple follicles 8-12mm. Left ovary: 3.5 x 3.1 x 2.3 cm, multiple follicles 6-10mm. Endometrial thickness: 8mm.
medicalTest.normalRange: Ovarian volume <10 cm³, <12 follicles per ovary
medicalTest.interpretation: Polycystic ovarian morphology consistent with PCOS. No dominant follicles or cysts noted.
recommendations: Consider ovulation induction if pregnancy desired

medicalTest.results: Glucose: 92mg/dL, HbA1c: 5.7%, Total Cholesterol: 198mg/dL, LDL: 118mg/dL, HDL: 42mg/dL, Triglycerides: 145mg/dL, TSH: 2.1 mIU/L
medicalTest.interpretation: Improved glycemic control. Thyroid function normal on current levothyroxine dose. Lipid profile shows improvement.
recommendations: Maintain current diet and exercise regimen

medicalTest.results: Testosterone: 65 ng/dL, Free Testosterone: 2.1 pg/mL, DHEA-S: 285 μg/dL, Androstenedione: 3.2 ng/mL, LH: 8.5 mIU/mL, FSH: 5.2 mIU/mL
medicalTest.normalRange: Testosterone: 15-70 ng/dL, LH: 5-20 mIU/mL, FSH: 3-20 mIU/mL
medicalTest.interpretation: Elevated testosterone and LH consistent with PCOS. Good response to anti-androgen therapy.
recommendations: Consider increasing dose if hirsutism persists

externalReports.summary: Comprehensive nutritional assessment for PCOS management. Patient educated on anti-inflammatory diet principles.
recommendations: Limit refined sugars and processed foods

patientHistory.description: Primary hypogonadism diagnosed after presenting with fatigue, decreased libido, and erectile dysfunction. Initial testosterone level 180 ng/dL.
patientHistory.notes: Patient showing good response to testosterone replacement therapy. Fertility preservation with hCG.

patientHistory.description: Moderate obstructive sleep apnea diagnosed via sleep study. AHI of 22 events per hour.
patientHistory.notes: Good compliance with CPAP therapy. Daytime symptoms significantly improved.

diagnosisTreatment.description: Primary testicular failure with low testosterone and elevated LH/FSH levels. Klinefelter syndrome ruled out with normal karyotype.
diagnosisTreatment.treatmentPlan: Testosterone cypionate injections every 2 weeks. Monitor testosterone levels, hematocrit, and PSA. Fertility counseling provided.
diagnosisTreatment.treatmentResponse: Excellent response with testosterone levels now 650 ng/dL. Improved energy, libido, and muscle mass.
diagnosisTreatment.notes: Consider dose adjustment if hematocrit continues to rise. Patient desires to maintain fertility.

medicalTest.results: Total Testosterone: 650 ng/dL, Free Testosterone: 15.2 pg/mL, LH: 0.8 mIU/mL, FSH: 1.2 mIU/mL, Estradiol: 35 pg/mL
medicalTest.normalRange: Total Testosterone: 300-1000 ng/dL, Free Testosterone: 8.7-25.1 pg/mL
medicalTest.interpretation: Excellent response to testosterone replacement therapy. Suppressed LH/FSH expected with exogenous testosterone.

medicalTest.results: Hemoglobin: 16.8 g/dL, Hematocrit: 51%, RBC: 5.2 M/μL, WBC: 6.8 K/μL, Platelets: 285 K/μL
medicalTest.interpretation: Mild elevation in hematocrit secondary to testosterone therapy. Within acceptable range.

externalReports.summary: Overnight polysomnography reveals moderate obstructive sleep apnea with AHI of 22 events per hour.

patientHistory.description: Oligomenorrhea with cycles ranging from 45-90 days. No clear etiology identified yet.
patientHistory.notes: Patient prefers natural approach initially. Considering hormonal evaluation if no improvement.

patientHistory.description: Mild iron deficiency anemia likely secondary to heavy menstrual bleeding during irregular cycles.
patientHistory.notes: Hemoglobin improved from 9.8 to 11.2 g/dL over 6 months. Good tolerance of iron supplements.

diagnosisTreatment.description: Absent menstruation for 4 months following previous oligomenorrhea pattern. Pregnancy ruled out.
diagnosisTreatment.treatmentPlan: Comprehensive hormonal workup including thyroid, prolactin, and reproductive hormones. Consider progestin challenge test.
diagnosisTreatment.treatmentResponse: Withdrawal bleeding achieved after progestin challenge. Awaiting hormone results.
diagnosisTreatment.notes: Patient anxious about fertility. Reassurance provided about reversible nature of condition.

medicalTest.results: LH: 3.2 mIU/mL, FSH: 4.8 mIU/mL, Estradiol: 45 pg/mL, Prolactin: 18 ng/mL, TSH: 1.8 mIU/L, Testosterone: 32 ng/dL
medicalTest.normalRange: LH: 5-20 mIU/mL, FSH: 3-20 mIU/mL, Estradiol: 30-400 pg/mL (cycle dependent)
medicalTest.interpretation: Low-normal reproductive hormones suggesting hypothalamic dysfunction. Thyroid and prolactin normal.
recommendations: Repeat in 3 months if cycles don't normalize

externalReports.summary: Evaluation for nutritional factors contributing to menstrual irregularities. BMI 19.2, suggesting possible energy deficit.

patientHistory.description: Type 2 diabetes diagnosed during routine screening. HbA1c was 8.2% at diagnosis.
patientHistory.notes: Excellent diabetes management. HbA1c reduced to 6.4% with lifestyle changes and medication.

patientHistory.description: Essential hypertension diagnosed concurrently with diabetes. Average BP 158/94 mmHg at diagnosis.
patientHistory.notes: Blood pressure well controlled on current regimen. Home monitoring shows consistent readings <130/80.

diagnosisTreatment.treatment: ACE inhibitor therapy and blood sugar optimization
diagnosisTreatment.description: Early diabetic kidney disease with microalbuminuria detected on routine screening. eGFR 75 mL/min/1.73m².
diagnosisTreatment.treatmentPlan: Optimize diabetes control with HbA1c target <7%. Nephrology consultation arranged. Blood pressure control <130/80 mmHg.
diagnosisTreatment.treatmentResponse: Microalbumin levels stable. eGFR improved to 82 mL/min/1.73m². Good diabetes control maintained.
sideEffects: Mild dry cough from ACE inhibitor
diagnosisTreatment.notes: Consider adding SGLT2 inhibitor if HbA1c rises or kidney function declines.

medicalTest.results: HbA1c: 6.4%, Fasting Glucose: 118 mg/dL, Microalbumin: 25 mg/g creatinine, eGFR: 82 mL/min/1.73m²
medicalTest.interpretation: Excellent diabetes control. Stable kidney function with improving trend.

externalReports.summary: Annual diabetic retinal screening shows no evidence of diabetic retinopathy. Mild cataracts noted.

patientHistory.description: Stage II endometriosis diagnosed via laparoscopy after chronic pelvic pain. Endometriomas removed from both ovaries.
patientHistory.notes: Good symptom control with dienogest. Pain scores reduced from 8/10 to 3/10.

patientHistory.description: Chronic fatigue syndrome diagnosed after ruling out other causes. Symptoms persist >6 months with significant functional impairment.
patientHistory.notes: Gradual improvement with pacing and energy conservation strategies. Working with occupational therapist.

diagnosisTreatment.treatment: Fertility preservation and assisted reproduction planning
diagnosisTreatment.description: 18-month history of infertility in setting of endometriosis. Ovarian reserve testing shows diminished reserve.
diagnosisTreatment.treatmentPlan: Complete fertility workup. Consider ovulation induction vs. IVF depending on tubal status and partner factors.
diagnosisTreatment.treatmentResponse: Partner's semen analysis normal. HSG shows patent tubes. Proceeding with ovulation induction.
diagnosisTreatment.notes: Patient counseled about impact of endometriosis on fertility. Good prognosis with treatment.

medicalTest.results: AMH: 1.8 ng/mL, FSH: 8.2 mIU/mL, Estradiol: 42 pg/mL, Antral Follicle Count: 12
medicalTest.interpretation: Diminished ovarian reserve for age but still within treatable range for fertility treatments.
recommendations: Consider fertility treatments sooner rather than later

externalReports.summary: HSG demonstrates patent fallopian tubes bilaterally with normal uterine cavity contour.
recommendations: No contraindication to IVF if needed

patientHistory.description: Moderate BPH with prostate volume 55cc on ultrasound. IPSS score 18 indicating moderate symptoms.
patientHistory.notes: Good symptom improvement. IPSS score reduced to 8. PSA stable at 2.1 ng/mL.

patientHistory.description: Gradual onset of hypogonadal symptoms with borderline low testosterone levels. Age-related decline vs. pathological cause being evaluated.
patientHistory.notes: Lifestyle modifications attempted first. Patient hesitant about hormone therapy due to prostate concerns.

diagnosisTreatment.diagnosis: Lower Urinary Tract Symptoms secondary to BPH
diagnosisTreatment.description: Moderate LUTS with good response to medical therapy. Patient avoiding surgical intervention at this time.
diagnosisTreatment.treatmentPlan: Combination therapy with tamsulosin and finasteride. Annual monitoring with PSA, symptom scores, and uroflowmetry.
diagnosisTreatment.treatmentResponse: Significant symptom improvement. Uroflow shows increased peak flow rate from 8 to 14 mL/s.
diagnosisTreatment.notes: Patient counseled about sexual side effects. Consider surgical options if medical therapy fails.

medicalTest.interpretation: Stable PSA levels on finasteride therapy. No concerning trend.
recommendations: Any doubling of PSA warrants evaluation

medicalTest.results: Total Testosterone: 285 ng/dL, Free Testosterone: 6.8 pg/mL, SHBG: 45 nmol/L
medicalTest.normalRange: Total Testosterone: 300-1000 ng/dL, Free Testosterone: 8.7-25.1 pg/mL
medicalTest.interpretation: Borderline low testosterone levels. Free testosterone below normal range.
recommendations: Consider testosterone therapy after BPH stabilized

externalReports.summary: TRUS shows enlarged prostate gland with heterogeneous echo pattern consistent with BPH. No suspicious lesions identified.
recommendations: No biopsy indicated at this time
